archetype_name: Family Weekend Advanced: South African Braai & Potjie
name: Cape Malay Chicken Potjie with Turmeric Rice
description: A slow-braised chicken thigh potjie with Cape Malay spice, apricots, and chutney, served with fragrant turmeric basmati rice. Built for the braai fire with a steady simmer and rich, layered flavor.
prep_steps: Light a medium braai fire for steady coals; place a potjie or heavy pot over indirect heat.
Rinse 2 cups basmati rice until water runs clear; drain well.
Peel and slice 2 large onions; mince 4 cloves garlic.
Measure spices: 2 tbsp masala spice blend, 1 tsp turmeric powder (split: 1/2 tsp for potjie, 1/2 tsp for rice), 1 tsp cumin seeds, 1 tsp coriander seeds, 2 bay leaves.
Season 1.2 kg chicken thighs with 1 tsp salt and 1/2 tsp black pepper.
cook_steps: Heat 2 tbsp sunflower oil in the potjie over the coals until shimmering.
Brown chicken thighs skin-side down 6–8 minutes, turn and brown 3–4 minutes more; remove to a tray.
Add sliced onions; cook 6–8 minutes until soft and lightly browned. Add minced garlic; cook 30 seconds.
Stir in cumin seeds, coriander seeds, masala spice blend, and 1/2 tsp turmeric powder; toast 30–60 seconds until fragrant.
Add 1 can (400 g) diced tomatoes, 1/2 cup chutney, 2 bay leaves, and 2 cups chicken stock; bring to a gentle simmer.

Return chicken to the pot skin-side up; tuck in apricot quarters. Adjust heat for a very gentle bubble, cover, and simmer 60–75 minutes until chicken is tender and sauce thickens. Stir occasionally to prevent sticking.
Taste and season with 1/2 tsp salt and 1/2 tsp black pepper (or to taste). Keep warm at the side of the fire.

For the rice: In a pot on the stovetop, combine rinsed basmati rice, 3 cups chicken stock, 1/2 tsp turmeric powder, and a pinch of salt. Bring to a boil, then reduce to low, cover, and cook 12–15 minutes until liquid is absorbed. Rest covered 5 minutes, then fluff.
Serve chicken and sauce over turmeric rice. Scatter chopped coriander on top.
